Yu-Ning Wong is an oncologist and the lead author of the newly published prostate cancer study in the journal of the American Medical Association.
But as we just heard Dr. Wong acknowledge, there is disagreement within the medical profession over the study's controversial finding.
One of those who questions the study's result is Dr. Mark Litwin, a professor of urology and public health at UCLA, who told me he had problems with how the study how the study was conducted.
The study that she led was methodologically terrific, and I commend her for doing a great amount of work.
The problem is you can't take shortcuts in research.
And unfortunately, trying to draw conclusions that she did out of what's called an observational study, which is what this was, is problematic.
My principle issues are this.
In her study, she reported that elderly men who were treated for prostate cancer had longer survivals than elderly men who were just observed for their prostate cancer.

My contention is that in fact the benefit and survival that those men who were treated derived was not because they were treated from their prostate cancer but because they were inherently healthier to begin with.
So it was a selection issue.
That's my primary contention.
The second is that even though the men who were treated were less likely to die from prostate cancer, the difference was fairly small.
So among the men who were treated, 6.8 percent of them died over the next 12 years.

But really the difference in survival between 6.8 percent of men dying versus 8 percent of men dying is not dramatic enough that we should put the accelerator to the floor and start treating many, many elderly men who are diagnosed with prostate cancer.
To follow up on that point then, does this report muddy the water for newly diagnosed patients who already face a wide ranged of complicated choices?
Well, I think that this report doesn't muddy the water as much as it is provocative.
It means that we really ought to be attentive to individual patient preferences when men are diagnosed with prostrate cancer.
That's true for any man diagnosed with prostate cancer, but particularly for elderly men with prostate cancer.
The issue that's really key is what's important in prostate cancer treatment is not only survival but also quality of life.

I'd suppose you could call that a quality of life issue.
But the question is what is an example of over-treatment?

An example of over-treatment would be taking a 78-year-old man who has significant other medical problems and saying, hey, this study show that you're more likely to live longer if we treat your prostate cancer so let's sign you up for radiation or surgery.
That individual is really unlikely to benefit from treatment for his prostate cancer, but is very likely to end up with quality of life problems after the treatment.
Why has watchful waiting, Doctor, been so prevalent as a diagnosis?
